description: From French prompt, from Latin prōmptus (“visible, apparent, evident”), past participle of prōmō (“to take or bring out or forth, produce, bring to light”), from prō (“forth, forward”) + emō (“to take, acquire, buy”).

adjectives.description: prompt (comparative more prompt, superlative most prompt)

examples: He was very prompt at getting a new job.

entries.meaning: (finance) Front: closest or nearest, in futures trading.
(business, dated) A time limit given for payment of an account for produce purchased, this limit varying with different goods.
(computing) A sequence of characters that is displayed to indicate that a computer is ready to receive input.
examples: I filled in my name where the prompt appeared on the computer screen but my account wasn't recognized.

entries.meaning: (writing) A suggestion for inspiration given to an author.
(machine learning) Textual input given to a large language model in order to have it generate a desired output.

verbs.description: prompt (third-person singular simple present prompts, present participle prompting, simple past and past participle prompted)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To lead (someone) toward what they should say or do.
examples: I prompted him to get a new job.

entries.meaning: (transitive, theater and television) To show or tell an actor/person the words they should be saying, or actions they should be doing.
examples: If he forgets his words I will prompt him.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To initiate; to cause or lead to.
examples: On October 6, 1927, Warner Bros. released The Jazz Singer, the first sound-synched feature film, prompting a technological shift of unprecedented speed and unstoppable force. Within two years, nearly every studio release was a talkie.
